answers.answer: I am not a physician but a volunteer and the   mom of a type 1 diabetic and the daughter of a type 2 diabetic.You do not say whether your daughter is on shots or the pump. If your daughter is on shots she needs to check and have her shots about the same time everyday otherwise she can go high. for example if she always checks at 7 am and takes her shot and then the next day not test till 9 or 10-  she could go high depending on what type of insulin regimen she is on.   However is she is on the pump it should not matter, if her basal rate (background insulin rates) is set properly she should be with in her target range.When my daughter was on shots if she wanted to sleep late I would get up test her blood and give her insulin, or she would test eat and g back top bed. That is one reason we switched to the insulin pump so that she did not have to have a regimented lifestyle.I would suggest talking with your doctor and see how much of a time span he says your daughter can go with out check from her normal time.

I HAVE A QUESTION IN REGUARD TO HYPOGLYCEMIA I WAS TOLD THAT I HAVE HYPOGLYCEMIA WHEN I WAS 7 YEAR OLD. MY MOTHER TOLD ME I ALWAYS HAD THE SHAKES WHEN I WAS A BABY. IN THE PAST SIX MONTHS I HAVE HAD RE OCCURING BOUTS OF HYPOGLYCEMIA AND AFTER EVERY MEAL FEEL EXCESSIVLY TIERD. I HAVE SYMPTOMS AFTER HAVING COFFEE IN THE MORNING. I HAVE ALSO NOTICED THAT I GET A RESTLESS LEG WHEN I LAY DOWN TO GO TO BED AND FEEL VERY TIERD BUT UNABLE TO GO TO SLEEP. ALWAYS THIRSTY AND FREQUENTLY URINATE. I AM WORRIED THAT I MAY NOW BE DIABETIC IS THIS POSSIBLE?

L28,I am not a physician, but the mom of a volunteer and the mom of a type one diabetic.  I would suggest you talk to your doctor.Here are some of the more common symptoms of diabetesFrequent urinationExcessive thirstUnexplained weight lossExtreme hungerSudden vision changesTingling or numbness in hands or feetFeeling very tired much of the timeVery dry skinSores that is slow to healYeast infectionsNausea, vomiting, or stomach pains may accompany some of these symptoms in the abrupt onset of insulin-dependent diabetes, now called type 1 diabetes.Sweet smelling urineSweet smelling breathIf you think that you have some of the symptoms. (Most people have some not all) I would suggest your contact your doctor.

question: I am wondering what the ideal time is to test in the morning.  Right when you get up or is it ok to wait until right before you eat breakfast.My daughter sometimes wakes at 6:30 but doesn't eat until 8:00.  Should I make sure she tests right away or is it ok to wait until a few minutes before she eats?Thanks!
title: Timing of glucose test
